Album Review: Atlas Genius - Inanimate Objects

By James Bithell

Keith and Michael Jeffery's second album is a determined and confident return

Review: 45 Years

By James Bithell

Andrew Haigh's film of an ordinary couple celebrating an anniversary is 'pure poetry in the domestic space', says Laura Hancock

Review: Ruby Wax: Sane New World

A well poised and witty discussion of mental illness offers up a healthy dose of catharsis for both audience and comic. Rhys Thompson reviews

TV Review: This is England '90 - Episode 1

This first episode does not quite live up to what we expect from the This is England franchise, but it isn't entirely unredeemable either, says Simran Virdee.

Review: The Visit

Unpretentious and darkly funny, The Visit marks a return to form for M Night Shyamalan, says Lauren McNeilage

Album Review: Beirut - No No No

By James Bithell

Alt-folk mavericks strip back to the bones on their latest record, but No No No is all the more nimble for it, says Liam Mullally

Practical advice on what to pack and what to leave at home

TV Review: Fear the Walking Dead - Series 1 Episode 3: 'The Dog'

An increased sense of impending danger is what makes this the most thrilling episode of the series so far, says Liam Dooley

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Jody Kamali

Part sketch, part theatre, part everything else, surrealist comic Kamali's Spectacular! is as delightful as it is bewildering

Review: Legend

Tom Hardy is becoming such a legendary actor that for this gangster film they chose to cast him twice, says Simran Virdee

TV Review: An Inspector Calls

Irritating music and script changes blunt the impact of the BBC's stylish adaptation of J.B. Priestley's classic play, says Rhys Thompson

Smashing the stained-glass ceiling

Bishop of Stockport Libby Lane talks to Liam Mullally about becoming one of the first female Anglican bishops and the challenges facing the Church in the future

Album Review: Gold Celeste - The Glow

Gold Celeste's debut album is remarkably tranquil but lacks the adventurous streak of other psych-pop records

Album Review: Destroyer - Poison Season

By James Bithell

Poison Season is refreshingly intricate in an indie genre overcrowded with clashing chords and overly direct choruses, writes Arun Kakar

TV Review: The Great British Bake Off - Series 6 Episode 6

As Bake Off continues, the bakers attempt Pastry Week - with mixed results. Leah Huws reviews

Album Review: Kwabs - Love and War

By James Bithell

BBC Sound of 2015 nominee Kwabena Adjepong's debut album is both varied and profound in equal measures

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Owen Jones: The Politics Of Hope

By James Bithell

Guardian columnist and author shares ideas with a welcome vigor to a full house at The Assembly Rooms

TV Review: Lady Chatterley's Lover

Prettily shot and well-acted, but in robbing the story of so much of its physicality, this adaptation also robs it of its soul, says Lauren McNeilage

Album Review: Bullet For My Valentine - Venom

By James Bithell

Welsh metalcore outfit continue to fall just short

A National Treasure

Rachel Paix takes us through the decades of Audrey Hepburn's iconic style
